lymphatic_network.formula: The lymphatic system is a network of vessels that collect excess tissue fluid and return it to the blood
lymphatic_network.correct: Lymphatic capillaries drain interstitial fluid, which becomes lymph and passes through lymph nodes before returning to blood

wrong.answer: Lymphatic vessels carry blood
wrong.fix: Lymphatic vessels carry lymph (tissue fluid), not blood; blood vessels carry blood
wrong.action: Lymph = tissue fluid collected from tissues; Blood = circulates in blood vessels

wrong.answer: Lymph flows from lymph nodes to tissues
wrong.fix: Lymph flows FROM tissues THROUGH lymph nodes TO blood
wrong.action: Direction: tissues → lymphatic capillaries → lymph nodes → thoracic duct → blood

wrong.answer: The lymphatic system has its own pump
wrong.fix: Lymph movement depends on skeletal muscle contraction and valves; there is no lymphatic pump
wrong.action: Lymph moves by: muscle contraction, breathing movements, one-way valves

persistent.gap: Confusion about lymphatic system structure and flow
persistent.action: Trace: tissue fluid → lymph capillaries → lymph vessels → lymph nodes → thoracic duct → subclavian vein

lymph_nodes.formula: Lymph nodes are small organs that filter lymph and provide sites for immune cell activation
lymph_nodes.correct: Lymph nodes contain B cells in follicles, T cells in the paracortex, and macrophages that filter pathogens from lymph

wrong.answer: Lymph nodes produce lymph
wrong.fix: Lymph nodes filter and process lymph; they don't produce it
wrong.action: Lymph is tissue fluid; nodes filter it and activate immune cells

wrong.answer: Lymph nodes only contain B cells
wrong.fix: Lymph nodes contain B cells, T cells, dendritic cells, and macrophages in distinct zones
wrong.action: Follicles = B cells; Paracortex = T cells; Throughout = macrophages, DCs

wrong.answer: Pathogens pass through lymph nodes unchanged
wrong.fix: Macrophages in lymph nodes trap and destroy pathogens; antigens are presented to lymphocytes
wrong.action: Nodes = filter pathogens + activate lymphocytes

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of lymph node structure and function
persistent.action: Lymph nodes: filter pathogens, house lymphocytes, site of adaptive immune activation

primary_lymphoid.formula: Primary lymphoid organs (bone marrow and thymus) are sites where lymphocytes develop and mature
primary_lymphoid.correct: B cells mature in bone marrow; T cells migrate to thymus for maturation and selection

wrong.answer: Lymphocytes mature in lymph nodes
wrong.error: Confusing primary and secondary lymphoid organs
wrong.fix: Lymphocytes mature in primary organs (bone marrow, thymus); they're activated in secondary organs
wrong.action: Primary = development; Secondary = activation

wrong.answer: B cells mature in the thymus
wrong.error: Switching B and T cell maturation sites
wrong.fix: B cells mature in Bone marrow; T cells mature in Thymus (B=Bone, T=Thymus)
wrong.action: B = Bone marrow; T = Thymus (both start with same letter)

wrong.answer: The spleen is a primary lymphoid organ
wrong.fix: The spleen is a secondary lymphoid organ; only bone marrow and thymus are primary
wrong.action: Primary: bone marrow + thymus only; Spleen = secondary

persistent.gap: Confusion between primary and secondary lymphoid organs
persistent.action: Primary (development): bone marrow, thymus; Secondary (activation): lymph nodes, spleen, MALT

secondary_lymphoid.formula: Secondary lymphoid organs (lymph nodes, spleen, MALT) are sites where adaptive immune responses are initiated
secondary_lymphoid.correct: Antigens and activated dendritic cells enter secondary organs where they encounter and activate naive lymphocytes

wrong.answer: Secondary lymphoid organs produce lymphocytes
wrong.fix: Secondary organs activate mature lymphocytes; production occurs in bone marrow
wrong.action: Primary = production; Secondary = activation of mature cells

wrong.answer: The thymus is a secondary lymphoid organ
wrong.fix: The thymus is primary (T cell development); secondary organs include lymph nodes and spleen
wrong.action: Thymus = primary; Lymph nodes, spleen, MALT = secondary

wrong.answer: Secondary organs only respond to blood-borne pathogens
wrong.fix: Different secondary organs sample different sources: lymph nodes (tissue), spleen (blood), MALT (mucosa)
wrong.action: Nodes = tissue antigens; Spleen = blood antigens; MALT = mucosal antigens

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of secondary lymphoid organ functions
persistent.action: Secondary organs: lymph nodes (lymph), spleen (blood), MALT (mucosa) = sites of antigen encounter

thymus.formula: The thymus is where T cells undergo maturation, positive selection, and negative selection
thymus.correct: T cells that recognise MHC are positively selected; those reacting strongly to self-antigens are negatively selected (deleted)

wrong.answer: All T cells that enter the thymus survive
wrong.fix: ~95% of T cells die in thymus through selection; only self-tolerant, MHC-recognising cells survive
wrong.action: Most T cells die in thymus = ensures self-tolerance

wrong.answer: The thymus increases in size throughout life
wrong.fix: The thymus is largest in childhood and gradually shrinks (involutes) with age
wrong.action: Thymus involutes = immune function changes with age

wrong.answer: Negative selection removes cells that can't recognise MHC
wrong.fix: Positive selection saves MHC-recognising cells; negative selection removes self-reactive cells
wrong.action: Positive = must recognise MHC; Negative = must not react to self

persistent.action: Positive selection: keeps MHC-recognising T cells; Negative selection: removes self-reactive T cells

spleen.formula: The spleen filters blood, removes old red blood cells, and houses immune cells that respond to blood-borne pathogens
spleen.correct: The white pulp contains lymphoid tissue for immune responses; the red pulp filters blood and recycles iron

wrong.answer: The spleen filters lymph like lymph nodes
wrong.error: Confusing spleen and lymph node function
wrong.fix: The spleen filters blood; lymph nodes filter lymph
wrong.action: Spleen = blood filter; Lymph nodes = lymph filter

wrong.answer: The spleen is essential for survival
wrong.error: Not knowing spleen can be removed
wrong.fix: People can survive without a spleen, though they're more susceptible to certain infections
wrong.action: Spleen removal = increased risk of encapsulated bacterial infections

wrong.answer: The spleen only has immune functions
wrong.fix: The spleen also removes old red blood cells and recycles iron from haemoglobin
wrong.action: Spleen functions: immune (white pulp) + blood filtering (red pulp)

persistent.action: Spleen: white pulp (immune cells, antibody responses) + red pulp (RBC removal, iron recycling)

malt.formula: Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) provides immune surveillance at mucosal surfaces
malt.correct: MALT includes tonsils, Peyer's patches (intestines), and other lymphoid tissues at mucosal barriers

wrong.answer: MALT is only in the digestive tract
wrong.fix: MALT is found at all mucosal surfaces: respiratory, digestive, urogenital
wrong.action: MALT at all mucosae: BALT (bronchi), GALT (gut), NALT (nasal)

wrong.answer: Tonsils have no immune function
wrong.fix: Tonsils are MALT that samples pathogens entering through the mouth and nose
wrong.action: Tonsils = first line MALT for inhaled/ingested pathogens

wrong.answer: MALT produces systemic immunity only
wrong.fix: MALT produces secretory IgA for mucosal protection, as well as contributing to systemic immunity
wrong.action: MALT → IgA at mucosal surfaces + systemic responses

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of mucosal immune system
persistent.action: MALT: located at mucosae, samples pathogens, produces IgA, protects body entry points

lymphocyte_circulation.formula: Lymphocytes continuously circulate between blood, lymph, and lymphoid tissues to survey for antigens
lymphocyte_circulation.correct: Naive lymphocytes enter lymph nodes via high endothelial venules and exit via efferent lymphatics if not activated

wrong.answer: Lymphocytes stay in one location
wrong.fix: Lymphocytes constantly recirculate, allowing them to encounter antigens throughout the body
wrong.action: Recirculation = maximises chance of meeting matching antigen

wrong.answer: Lymphocytes enter lymph nodes through lymphatic vessels
wrong.fix: Lymphocytes enter nodes from blood via HEVs; they exit via lymphatics
wrong.action: Entry: blood → HEV → node; Exit: node → lymphatics → blood

wrong.answer: Activated lymphocytes return to blood immediately
wrong.fix: Activated lymphocytes are retained in lymph nodes for proliferation before re-entering circulation
wrong.action: Activation → retention → proliferation → exit to tissues

persistent.action: Trace: blood → HEV → lymph node → lymphatics → thoracic duct → blood (continuous loop)

sentences.text: The lymphatic system collects excess {{d1}} fluid from tissues and returns it to the {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What is the fluid between cells called?

d2.tooltip: Where does lymph eventually drain to?

sentences.text: Once inside lymphatic vessels, tissue fluid is called {{d1}}, which passes through {{d2}} before reaching the blood.

d1.tooltip: What is fluid called once in lymphatic vessels?

d2.tooltip: What structures filter lymph?

sentences.text: Lymph movement relies on {{d1}} muscle contraction and one-way {{d2}} because there is no central pump.

d1.tooltip: Which muscle type helps move lymph?

d2.tooltip: What prevents lymph from flowing backward?

primary.title: Development Sites
primary.instructions: Learn where lymphocytes develop and mature.

sentences.text: Primary lymphoid organs are where lymphocytes {{d1}} and become {{d2}} before encountering antigens.

d1.tooltip: What happens to lymphocytes in primary organs?

d2.tooltip: What state are lymphocytes in after leaving primary organs?

sentences.text: B cells mature in the {{d1}}, while T cells migrate to the {{d2}} for maturation.

d1.tooltip: Where do B cells mature?

d2.tooltip: Where do T cells mature?

sentences.text: The thymus is located in the {{d1}} and is largest during {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Where is the thymus located?

d2.tooltip: When is the thymus largest?

secondary.title: Activation Sites
secondary.instructions: Learn where immune responses are initiated.

sentences.text: Secondary lymphoid organs are sites where {{d1}} lymphocytes encounter {{d2}} and become activated.

d1.tooltip: What state are lymphocytes in when they enter secondary organs?

d2.tooltip: What do lymphocytes encounter in secondary organs?

sentences.text: Lymph nodes filter {{d1}} from tissues, while the spleen filters {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What fluid do lymph nodes filter?

d2.tooltip: What fluid does the spleen filter?

sentences.text: {{d1}}-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) provides immune surveillance at {{d2}} surfaces.

d1.tooltip: What type of tissue is MALT associated with?

d2.tooltip: What surfaces does MALT protect?

circulation.title: Lymphocyte Movement
circulation.instructions: Understand how lymphocytes patrol the body.

sentences.text: Lymphocytes continuously {{d1}} between blood, lymph, and lymphoid tissues to survey for {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What do lymphocytes do throughout the body?

d2.tooltip: What are lymphocytes looking for?

sentences.text: Naive lymphocytes enter lymph nodes from the {{d1}} via specialised vessels called high {{d2}} venules.

d1.tooltip: From where do lymphocytes enter nodes?

d2.tooltip: What type of venules allow lymphocyte entry?

sentences.text: If not activated, lymphocytes exit nodes via {{d1}} lymphatics and eventually return to the {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What type of lymphatics carry lymph away from nodes?

d2.tooltip: Where does lymph eventually drain to?

network.title: Lymph Node Structure
network.instructions: Understand the organisation of lymph nodes.

sentences.text: Lymph enters nodes via {{d1}} lymphatics and exits via {{d2}} lymphatics after filtering.

d1.tooltip: What type of lymphatics bring lymph to nodes?

d2.tooltip: What type of lymphatics carry lymph away?

sentences.text: B cells are concentrated in {{d1}} in the cortex, while T cells are found in the {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Where are B cells located in lymph nodes?

d2.tooltip: Where are T cells located in lymph nodes?

sentences.text: Macrophages throughout the node {{d1}} pathogens from lymph, while dendritic cells {{d2}} antigens to lymphocytes.

d1.tooltip: What do macrophages do to pathogens?

d2.tooltip: What do dendritic cells do with antigens?

primary.title: Thymic Selection
primary.instructions: Understand how T cells are selected in the thymus.

sentences.text: In positive selection, T cells that can recognise {{d1}} molecules are allowed to {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What molecules must T cells recognise?

d2.tooltip: What happens to T cells that pass positive selection?

sentences.text: In negative selection, T cells that react strongly to {{d1}} antigens are {{d2}} to prevent autoimmunity.

d1.tooltip: What antigens trigger deletion in negative selection?

d2.tooltip: What happens to self-reactive T cells?

sentences.text: Approximately {{d1}}% of T cells die during thymic selection, ensuring only {{d2}}-tolerant cells survive.

d1.tooltip: What percentage of T cells die in the thymus?

d2.tooltip: What must surviving T cells be tolerant to?

sentences.text: The spleen's {{d1}} pulp contains lymphoid tissue, while the {{d2}} pulp filters blood and removes old red blood cells.

d1.tooltip: Which pulp contains immune cells?

d2.tooltip: Which pulp filters blood?

sentences.text: MALT includes tonsils in the throat and {{d1}} patches in the {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What lymphoid structures are in the intestine?

d2.tooltip: Where are Peyer's patches located?

sentences.text: MALT produces secretory {{d1}} antibodies that provide protection at {{d2}} surfaces.

d1.tooltip: Which antibody class is secreted at mucosae?

d2.tooltip: Where does secretory IgA provide protection?

circulation.title: Lymphocyte Homing
circulation.instructions: Understand how lymphocytes find their destinations.

sentences.text: Lymphocytes express {{d1}} molecules that allow them to bind to specific {{d2}} on blood vessel walls.

d1.tooltip: What molecules help lymphocytes find destinations?

d2.tooltip: What molecules on vessels guide lymphocyte entry?

sentences.text: Activated lymphocytes are {{d1}} in lymph nodes while they proliferate, before being released to find {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What happens to activated lymphocytes initially?

d2.tooltip: Where do activated lymphocytes go?

sentences.text: Swollen lymph nodes during infection indicate {{d1}} proliferation and {{d2}} of immune cells within.

d1.tooltip: What cells proliferate in swollen nodes?

d2.tooltip: What causes the swelling?

network.title: Clinical Significance
network.instructions: Apply lymphatic understanding to clinical conditions.

sentences.text: {{d1}} occurs when lymphatic drainage is impaired, causing tissue {{d2}} due to fluid accumulation.

d1.tooltip: What is the condition of lymphatic blockage?

d2.tooltip: What symptom results from impaired drainage?

sentences.text: Cancer cells can spread through lymphatic vessels to regional lymph {{d1}}, a process called lymphatic {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Where do cancer cells first spread via lymphatics?

d2.tooltip: What is cancer spread called?

sentences.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy identifies the {{d1}} node draining a tumour to check for cancer {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Which node receives drainage first?

d2.tooltip: What does the biopsy check for?

primary.title: Immune Deficiencies
primary.instructions: Connect primary organ dysfunction to disease.

sentences.text: DiGeorge syndrome involves thymic {{d1}}, resulting in severe T cell {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What is underdevelopment of the thymus called?

d2.tooltip: What results from lack of thymic development?

sentences.text: Bone marrow failure affects production of {{d1}} blood cells, including B cells and cells of the {{d2}} lineage.

d1.tooltip: What cells are affected by marrow failure?

d2.tooltip: Which lineage produces granulocytes and monocytes?

sentences.text: Bone marrow transplantation can restore {{d1}} function by providing healthy {{d2}} cells.

d1.tooltip: What blood-forming function is restored?

d2.tooltip: What type of cells does transplant provide?

sentences.text: {{d1}} is the removal of the spleen, which increases susceptibility to {{d2}} bacterial infections.

d1.tooltip: What is surgical removal of the spleen called?

d2.tooltip: What type of bacteria are patients at risk for?

sentences.text: {{d1}} is cancer of lymphoid tissue that often presents as {{d2}} lymph nodes.

d1.tooltip: What is cancer of lymph nodes called?

d2.tooltip: How do lymph nodes appear in lymphoma?

sentences.text: Tonsillectomy removes tonsils but has minimal immune impact because other {{d1}} tissue compensates for {{d2}} immunity.

d1.tooltip: What other tissue compensates for tonsils?

d2.tooltip: What type of immunity do tonsils contribute to?

sentences.text: Lymph node examination is used in {{d1}} staging to determine cancer {{d2}} and treatment options.

d1.tooltip: What disease is staged using lymph nodes?

d2.tooltip: What does node involvement indicate?

sentences.text: Vaccines are often injected into tissue to allow {{d1}} cells to carry antigens to lymph {{d2}} for immune activation.

d1.tooltip: Which cells transport vaccine antigens?

d2.tooltip: Where are immune responses initiated?

sentences.text: Understanding lymphocyte {{d1}} helps design therapies that direct immune cells to {{d2}} or infected tissues.

d1.tooltip: What is lymphocyte movement called?

d2.tooltip: Where might we want to direct immune cells?
